head.title: How Now, Bronx Cow? An Oddity Puzzles Even the Police

hedline.hl1: How Now, Bronx Cow? An Oddity Puzzles Even the Police

abstract.p: Bronx borough parks commissioner William Castro assures police that fiberglass cow from Cow Parade art project placed on street in South Bronx had not been stolen from Manhattan herd; photo; list (M)

block.p: Everyone else had a cow. Why not the South Bronx?

Everyone else had a cow. Why not the South Bronx?
When the ''Cow Parade'' rolled into New York in March, directors of the Point, a Hunts Point community organization, wanted to get one of the fiberglass cows for themselves.

The group's effort began with the usual bovine banter: ''I wrote and said I had a beef with them,'' said Paul Lipson, the group's executive director. ''I told them Bronx artists would stampede their offices.''
Finally, on July 26, a truck pulled up to the Point. Inside was the coveted cow. The organization's directors placed it outside their building.

But the following Monday, Mr. Lipson got a call from the Bronx borough parks commissioner, William T. Castro. According to Mr. Castro, the police had called him to inquire about a stolen cow. Were any missing from the other boroughs? Because, the police said, the one in Hunts Point looked quite out of place.
''There have been some cases of cattle rustling, apparently,'' Mr. Lipson said. ''But I assured him that wasn't the case here.''

While there are hundreds of fiberglass cows in the Manhattan herd of the ''Cow Parade,'' only a few roam in the outer boroughs. Robert Lawson, a spokesman for the Parks Department, which is coordinating the project, said the Bronx had only five cows, only one of which is in the South Bronx.

''For this cow, it took considerable effort just crossing the Harlem River,'' said Parks Commissioner Henry Stern, who learned of the (not) stolen cow last week. ''But the cow is a happy cow, and we know now that the police will keep an eye on her.''
As for fitting in, Mr. Lipson said, ''I am happy to report that our cow has not been molested or moved or even tipped.''
